sn8.2:1.1: At one time Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Āḷavī, at the Aggāḷava Tree-shrine, together with his mentor, Venerable Nigrodhakappa.
sn8.2:1.2: Now at that time after Venerable Nigrodhakappa had finished his meal, on his return from alms-round, he would enter his dwelling and not emerge for the rest of that day, or the next.
sn8.2:1.3: And at that time Venerable Vaṅgīsa became dissatisfied, as lust infected his mind.
sn8.2:1.6: that I’ve become dissatisfied, with lust infecting my mind. How is it possible for someone else to dispel my discontent and give rise to satisfaction?
sn8.2:1.7: Why don’t I do it myself?”
sn8.2:1.8: Then, on the occasion of dispelling his own discontent and giving rise to satisfaction, he recited these verses:
sn8.2:2.2: along with all thoughts of the lay life,
sn8.2:2.3: they wouldn’t get entangled in anything;
sn8.2:2.4: unentangled, undesiring: that’s a real mendicant.
sn8.2:3.1: Whether on this earth or in the sky,
sn8.2:3.2: whatever in the world is included in form
sn8.2:3.3: wears out, it is all impermanent;
sn8.2:3.4: the thoughtful live having comprehended this truth.
sn8.2:4.1: People are bound to their attachments,
sn8.2:4.2: to what is seen, heard, felt, and thought.
sn8.2:4.3: Unstirred, dispel desire for these things;
sn8.2:4.4: for one called ‘a sage’ does not cling to them.
sn8.2:5.1: Attached to the sixty wrong views, and full of their own opinions,
sn8.2:5.2: ordinary people are fixed in wrong principles.
sn8.2:5.3: But that mendicant wouldn’t join a sectarian group,
sn8.2:5.4: still less would they utter lewd speech.
sn8.2:6.2: free of deceit, alert, without envy,
sn8.2:6.3: the sage has reached the state of peace;
sn8.2:6.4: and because he’s extinguished, he awaits his time.”
